question.title: Will a member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?
question.body:
Resolves **Yes** if one of these individuals is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024:

 - Donald Trump
 - Donald Trump Jr.
 - Eric Trump
 - Ivanka Trump
 - Tiffany Trump
 - Melania Trump
 - Barron Trump

metadata.background_info:
Donald John Trump is the 45th and current president of the United States. Before entering politics, he was a businessman and television personality. Trump won a surprise victory in the [2016 presidential election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_United_States_presidential_election), and sought re-election in the [2020 presidential election.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election)

The [Trump family](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Family_of_Donald_Trump) has a net worth reported to be in the single-digit billions, and is now one of the most prominent families in Republican politics. Trump has several adult children, and there is speculation that a Trump political dynasty may emerge in the coming years, with both [Donald Trump Jr. and Ivanka Trump suggested as possible contenders for the presidency.](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/jan/04/donald-trump-jr-ivanka-trump-2024-presidential-election-poll)

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of a Trump family member being the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Donald Trump's influence: Despite his controversial presidency and two impeachments, Donald Trump maintains significant support within the Republican Party. He has hinted at running again in 2024 and remains a powerful figure in GOP politics. 2. Other Trump family members: While Donald Trump is the most likely family member to run, other adult Trump children (Donald Jr., Eric, and Ivanka) have gained political experience and visibility during their father's presidency. However, none have held elected office or expressed clear intentions to run for president. 3. Current political landscape: The Republican Party is still largely influenced by Trump's base, but there are signs of some party members seeking to move away from Trump's influence. 4. Potential challengers: Several high-profile Republicans, such as Ron DeSantis, Mike Pence, and Nikki Haley, are positioning themselves for potential 2024 runs, which could split the non-Trump vote. 5. Time until the nomination: With over a year until the Republican primaries begin, much can change in the political landscape. 6. Legal challenges: Donald Trump faces several legal challenges that could potentially impact his ability to run or his popularity among voters. 7. Historical precedent: It's rare for a former president to run again after losing re-election, but it has happened (e.g., Grover Cleveland). Given these factors, Donald Trump remains the most likely Trump family member to secure the nomination if he decides to run. The other family members have much lower chances due to their lack of political experience and unclear intentions to run. While there are significant challenges and potential alternatives, Trump's enduring popularity within the Republican base and his proven ability to mobilize voters make him a strong contender if he chooses to run.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question may consider new candidates added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, [saying at a rally in March 2022](https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-promises-to-return-to-the-white-house-in-2024-2022-3), "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before".  [Early polling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.  

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of [June 2022](https://floridapolitics.com/archives/531919-ron-desantis-swats-away-2024-speculation-yet-again/)), though Fox News producers have [called him](https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2021/08/13/inside-fox-news-desantis-is-the-future-of-the-party-and-hes-taking-advantage/) "the future of the Republican Party".  DeSantis is a frequent [second-place favorite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) in polling behind Trump.

Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; [in April 2022](https://archive.ph/uFSD4), when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

reformat_metaculus_question.original_body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** for the candidate below who is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election.  All other candidates will resolve as **No**.  This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who recieves the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election, it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Donald Trump becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: As of now, Donald Trump remains a prominent figure in the Republican Party and has a strong base of supporters. 2. Trump's intentions: Trump has repeatedly hinted at and even announced his intention to run for president again in 2024. 3. Competition within the Republican Party: While there are other potential candidates like Ron DeSantis, Mike Pence, and Nikki Haley, Trump still holds significant influence over the party. 4. Legal challenges: Trump is facing several legal issues, which could potentially impact his candidacy. However, these challenges have not significantly diminished his support base so far. 5. Historical precedent: It's not uncommon for former presidents to seek nomination again, especially if they only served one term. 6. Party dynamics: The Republican Party has largely aligned itself with Trump's policies and rhetoric over the past few years. 7. Polling data: Early polls for the 2024 Republican primary consistently show Trump leading other potential candidates by a significant margin. 8. Time until the convention: The Republican National Convention is still some time away, which leaves room for changes in the political landscape. Given these factors, Trump appears to be in a strong position to secure the Republican nomination. However, there are still uncertainties and potential obstacles that could arise. The legal challenges he faces and the possibility of a strong alternative candidate emerging cannot be completely discounted. Considering all these factors, I would estimate a relatively high probability of Trump becoming the Republican nominee, but not a certainty.

question.title: Will Scotland hold an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if there is a referendum held in Scotland regarding Scotland's independence from the United Kingdom, and this referendum is held before May 3, 2024.  This referendum may be an "advisory" referendum; that is, it is not necessary for the referendum to have any legally binding effect.

It shall not be deemed resolved by a “wildcat” or “Catalan” style of referendum where the UK government has declined permission for the vote, nor by a vote organised by civil society institutions. A referendum must be deemed to have the consent of the London government

metadata.background_info:
Scotland is one of the UK’s four constituent nations - and its politics are currently dominated by the [Scottish National Party](https://whatscotlandthinks.org/), a party whose core aim is to remove Scotland from the UK and become an independent country. 

The SNP government in Edinburgh previously successfully negotiated with the UK-wide government for the right to hold a referendum, [which took place in 2014](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Scottish_independence_referendum). The “No” side (“Better Together”) won 55% to 45%. The SNP has, however, won every Scottish national election since that date.

The SNP wish to have a fresh vote - stating that Brexit has changed the terms of the argument. The UK government has, to date, refused to countenance permitting such a vote. Under the Scotland Act, the Edinburgh government does not have the power to hold one [without permission.](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1998/46/section/30)

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Scotland holding an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political climate: The Scottish National Party (SNP), which supports independence, remains the dominant political force in Scotland. However, they do not have an outright majority in the Scottish Parliament. 2. UK Government stance: The UK Government, led by the Conservative Party, has consistently opposed a second independence referendum, arguing that the 2014 vote was a 'once in a generation' event. 3. Legal framework: The UK Supreme Court ruled in November 2022 that the Scottish Parliament does not have the power to unilaterally hold a referendum on independence without Westminster's consent. 4. Time constraints: As of now (2023), there is less than a year until the resolution date. Organizing a referendum typically requires significant preparation time. 5. Public opinion: While support for independence has fluctuated, recent polls do not show an overwhelming majority in favor, which might influence political decisions. 6. Brexit impact: The UK's exit from the EU has changed the context since the 2014 referendum, but it hasn't led to an immediate surge in support for independence. 7. COVID-19 recovery: Both the UK and Scottish governments are focused on economic recovery post-pandemic, which may take precedence over constitutional matters. Given these factors, the probability of an official, sanctioned referendum occurring before May 3, 2024, appears to be very low. The main obstacles are: a) The UK Government's continued opposition to granting permission for a referendum. b) The legal requirement for Westminster's consent, as confirmed by the Supreme Court. c) The limited time remaining before the resolution date. d) The focus on other pressing issues like economic recovery. While the SNP continues to push for independence, the current political and legal landscape makes it highly unlikely that an official, sanctioned referendum will take place within the specified timeframe.

question.title: Will USA top the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve positively if the United States Olympic Team are the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. It will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It will resolve negatively if any team achieves a higher or equal ranking to the US team.

The medal table is calculated by taking all the medals won by each participating country and ordering by:

1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medals

metadata.background_info:
The 2024 Olympic games is a sporting competition which takes place every four years. It involves a range of different events across multiple sports.

At the Olympic Games, Gold, Silver and Bronze medals are awarded to 1st, 2nd and 3rd place in each event. (In some events two Bronze medals are awarded mostly combat sports).

The US team is one of the most successful teams in recent Olympics, topping the medal table in 2020, 2016, 2012, 2004, 2000. Will they repeat that in 2024?

*Related questions*

* [How many medals will Team USA win in Paris 2024?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/7665/total-medals-won-by-the-usa-at-paris-2024/)
* [Will France come in the Top 5 at Paris 2024?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/7669/france-home-game-advantage/

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the USA topping the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: The United States has consistently been a top performer at the Summer Olympics. They topped the medal table in the last three Summer Olympics (2016 Rio, 2020 Tokyo, and 2012 London). 2. Depth and breadth of talent: The USA has a large population, excellent sports infrastructure, and a strong sporting culture, which contributes to their success across a wide range of Olympic sports. 3. Competitive landscape: While the USA is strong, other countries like China, ROC (Russian Olympic Committee), and Japan have been close competitors in recent Olympics. 4. Home advantage: Unlike in Tokyo 2020, where Japan had a home advantage, or in Beijing 2008, where China had it, the USA won't have this advantage in Paris 2024. 5. Potential challenges: - The rise of other nations in traditionally strong US sports (e.g., track and field, swimming) - Possible changes in Olympic program that might affect medal distribution - Unforeseen circumstances like injuries to key athletes or geopolitical issues 6. Time until the event: With the Olympics still about a year away, there's time for changes in form, new talent to emerge, or unexpected events to occur. 7. COVID-19 impact: While the pandemic's direct impact may be lessened by 2024, its long-term effects on athlete preparation and national sports programs could still play a role. Given these factors, the USA remains in a strong position to top the medal table. Their consistent performance, depth of talent, and success across many sports give them an edge. However, the competition is fierce, and there's always a possibility of surprise performances from other nations.

question.title: Will France place in the Top 5 at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body:
This question will resolve positively if France place in the top 5 (ties resolve positively) at the Olympics being held in 2024. It will resolve ambiguously if the Olympics do not take place in 2024.

The medal table is calculated by taking the total number of medals won by each participating country and ordering by:

1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medal

metadata.background_info:
*Related Questions on Metaculus:*

* [How many medals will Team USA win at Paris 2024?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/7665/total-medals-won-by-the-usa-at-paris-2024/)
* [Will the Team USA top the medal table at Paris 2024?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/7664/usa-most-successful-olympic-team-in-paris/)

----

[There is a phenomenon at the Olympics where by the host country tends to outperform it's recent performances](https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/is-there-home-field-advantage-at-the-olympics/)

France is hosting the Olympics in 2021. Will they place significantly higher in the medal table than they have in recent years. [Their last 6 placings were](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France_at_the_Olympics#Medals_by_Summer_Games):

```
2000: 6th 
2004: 7th 
2008: 10th 
2012: 7th 
2016: 7th
2020: 8th
```

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of France placing in the Top 5 at the 2024 Paris Olympics, we need to consider several factors: 1. Home advantage: As the host country, France will have a significant advantage. Host nations often perform better due to increased funding, familiar conditions, and strong crowd support. 2. Recent performance: In the 2020 Tokyo Olympics (held in 2021), France finished 8th in the medal table with 33 medals (10 gold, 12 silver, 11 bronze). This shows they are already close to the top 5. 3. Historical performance: France has consistently been a strong performer in the Olympics. In 2016, they finished 7th, and in 2012, they were 7th as well. 4. Increased investment: Host countries typically increase their investment in sports programs leading up to the Olympics. France is likely to have boosted funding and support for their athletes in preparation for 2024. 5. Strong sports: France excels in several Olympic sports, including fencing, judo, cycling, and swimming. These strengths contribute to their medal count. 6. Competition: The top performers in recent Olympics have consistently been countries like the United States, China, Japan, Great Britain, and the Russian Olympic Committee (or Russian athletes competing under a neutral flag). France will need to outperform at least one of these nations to break into the top 5. 7. Motivation: Competing on home soil will likely provide extra motivation for French athletes to perform at their best. 8. Development time: With the question being created in 2021, France has had several years to prepare and develop their athletes specifically for this event. Given these factors, especially the home advantage and the likely increased investment in sports programs, France has a strong chance of improving on their recent 8th place finish and breaking into the top 5. However, the competition at the top is fierce, and it's not guaranteed.

question.title: Will BJP form the government after the next Indian general election in 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the BJP has a member sworn in as the next Indian Prime Minister following the next general elections.  All other parties will resolve as **No**.

This question will resolve for the next general election occurring after June 1, 2022 (currently expected for May 2024)

metadata.background_info:
India has a [parliamentary government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_India) system, with 543 single-member constituencies which use first-past-the-post voting to elect MPs to the [Lok Sabha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lok_Sabha), the lower house in Indian Parliament.  The [Prime Minister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India) is appointed by the President and a majority vote of the Lok Sabha; the Prime Minister then leads this governing coalition.  Elections must be held every 5 years, but elections may be called earlier if the President dissolves the Lok Sabha.

The Bhartiya Janata Party (BJP) has been in power at the Union government level since 2014, with [Narendra Modi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narendra_Modi) as Prime Minister, with the Indian National Congress (INC) as the main challenger. The next national elections are scheduled for May 2024.

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Which party will form the government after the next Indian general election in 2024? (BJP)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** for the party who has a member sworn in as the next Indian Prime Minister following the next general elections.  All other parties will resolve as **No**.

This question will resolve for the next general election occuring after June 1, 2022 (currently expected for May 2024)

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the BJP forming the government after the next Indian general election in 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: The BJP, led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, is currently the ruling party in India and has been in power since 2014. They have maintained a strong position in national politics. 2. Historical performance: The BJP won a clear majority in both the 2014 and 2019 general elections, demonstrating their ability to secure widespread support across the country. 3. Leadership: Narendra Modi remains a popular figure in Indian politics, with a strong personal brand that often transcends party lines. 4. Opposition: The main opposition, the Indian National Congress, has struggled to present a unified front and strong leadership to challenge the BJP effectively. 5. Regional parties: While regional parties play a significant role in Indian politics, they have not yet formed a cohesive national alternative to the BJP. 6. Economic factors: India's economy has faced challenges, including the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the BJP government's handling of the crisis and economic recovery efforts may influence voter sentiment. 7. Social and religious factors: The BJP's Hindu nationalist ideology continues to resonate with a significant portion of the Indian electorate. 8. Time until election: With the election still about a year away, there is time for political dynamics to shift, but major changes would be needed to significantly alter the current landscape. 9. Recent state election results: While the BJP has faced some setbacks in state elections, they have also secured victories in key states, maintaining their overall strong position. 10. Voter fatigue: After two terms in power, there might be some voter fatigue with the BJP, but this is balanced by the lack of a strong national alternative. Considering these factors, the BJP appears to be in a strong position to form the government again after the 2024 general election. While there are potential challenges and uncertainties, the combination of incumbent advantage, strong leadership, and a fragmented opposition suggests a favorable outlook for the BJP.

question.title: Will INC form the government after the next Indian general election in 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the INC has a member sworn in as the next Indian Prime Minister following the next general elections. All other parties will resolve as **No**.

This question will resolve for the next general election occurring after June 1, 2022 (currently expected for May 2024).

metadata.background_info:
India has a [parliamentary government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_India) system, with 543 single-member constituencies which use first-past-the-post voting to elect MPs to the [Lok Sabha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lok_Sabha), the lower house in Indian Parliament.  The [Prime Minister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India) is appointed by the President and a majority vote of the Lok Sabha; the Prime Minister then leads this governing coalition.  Elections must be held every 5 years, but elections may be called earlier if the President dissolves the Lok Sabha.

The Bhartiya Janata Party (BJP) has been in power at the Union government level since 2014, with [Narendra Modi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narendra_Modi) as Prime Minister, with the Indian National Congress (INC) as the main challenger. The next national elections are scheduled for May 2024.

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Which party will form the government after the next Indian general election in 2024? (INC)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** for the party who has a member sworn in as the next Indian Prime Minister following the next general elections.  All other parties will resolve as **No**.

This question will resolve for the next general election occuring after June 1, 2022 (currently expected for May 2024)

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the Indian National Congress (INC) forming the government after the next Indian general election in 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi has been in power since 2014 and won a significant majority in the 2019 elections. The INC, the main opposition party, has been struggling to regain its former prominence. 2. Recent electoral performance: The INC has faced significant losses in recent state elections and has been unable to form strong coalitions in many states. This trend suggests a weakening of their national presence. 3. Leadership issues: The INC has been grappling with leadership challenges, particularly regarding the role of the Gandhi family. This internal instability has affected the party's image and organizational strength. 4. BJP's strong position: The BJP has maintained a strong grip on power, with Prime Minister Modi remaining a popular figure despite some challenges. The party's nationalist agenda and economic policies continue to resonate with a significant portion of the electorate. 5. Anti-incumbency factor: While this could potentially work against the BJP, it hasn't significantly impacted their performance in recent elections. 6. Opposition unity: The INC has struggled to unite opposition parties against the BJP, which is crucial for challenging the ruling party's dominance. 7. Time until elections: With the elections still about a year away, there's potential for shifts in public opinion or unexpected events that could influence the outcome. However, current trends don't indicate a major swing towards the INC. 8. Historical precedent: It's rare in Indian politics for a party to lose power after just two terms, especially when the incumbent government maintains a strong majority. Given these factors, while it's not impossible for the INC to form the government in 2024, it appears highly unlikely based on current information and trends. The INC would need to overcome significant challenges and see a dramatic shift in public opinion to achieve this outcome.

question.title: Will Nikki Haley be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Nikki Haley is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, [saying at a rally in March 2022](https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-promises-to-return-to-the-white-house-in-2024-2022-3), "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before".  [Early polling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.  

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of [June 2022](https://floridapolitics.com/archives/531919-ron-desantis-swats-away-2024-speculation-yet-again/)), though Fox News producers have [called him](https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2021/08/13/inside-fox-news-desantis-is-the-future-of-the-party-and-hes-taking-advantage/) "the future of the Republican Party".  DeSantis is a frequent [second-place favorite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) in polling behind Trump.

Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; [in April 2022](https://archive.ph/uFSD4), when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Nikki Haley becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: As of now, Donald Trump is the frontrunner for the Republican nomination, with a significant lead in polls and strong support from the Republican base. 2. Haley's campaign performance: While Haley has gained some traction and is considered one of the more viable alternatives to Trump, she has struggled to gain substantial support in polls and primary contests so far. 3. Republican Party dynamics: The party seems to be still largely aligned with Trump's policies and persona, which makes it challenging for other candidates to break through. 4. Delegate count: Trump has been winning primaries and caucuses by large margins, accumulating a significant number of delegates. Haley would need to dramatically reverse this trend to have a chance at the nomination. 5. Historical precedent: It's rare for a party to nominate someone other than the clear frontrunner, especially when that frontrunner is a former president. 6. Time until convention: There is still time before the Republican National Convention, but Haley would need a major shift in the political landscape or a significant event to change the current trajectory. 7. Haley's persistence: Despite calls for her to drop out, Haley has vowed to stay in the race, which keeps her chances alive, albeit slim. 8. Potential unforeseen circumstances: Legal challenges or other unexpected events could potentially impact Trump's candidacy, which could benefit Haley. Given these factors, while it's not impossible for Haley to become the nominee, it appears highly unlikely at this point. Trump's dominance in the race, combined with the party's current alignment, makes it very difficult for Haley to secure the nomination barring extraordinary circumstances.

Party establishment support: There's little evidence that Ramaswamy has significant support from the Republican party establishment, which can be crucial in securing the nomination. 8. Media coverage: While Ramaswamy has received some media attention, it's not at the level of the frontrunners, which makes it harder for him to build widespread support. Given these factors, it appears highly unlikely that Vivek Ramaswamy will secure the Republican nomination. While unexpected events can always occur in politics, the current evidence suggests that his chances are very low.

question.title: Will Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Asa Hutchinson is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently considered; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, [saying at a rally in March 2022](https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-promises-to-return-to-the-white-house-in-2024-2022-3), "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before".  [Early polling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.  

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of [June 2022](https://floridapolitics.com/archives/531919-ron-desantis-swats-away-2024-speculation-yet-again/)), though Fox News producers have [called him](https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2021/08/13/inside-fox-news-desantis-is-the-future-of-the-party-and-hes-taking-advantage/) "the future of the Republican Party".  DeSantis is a frequent [second-place favorite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) in polling behind Trump.

Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; [in April 2022](https://archive.ph/uFSD4), when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

While there's always a possibility of unexpected events or shifts in the political landscape, the odds are heavily stacked against him at this point.

question.title: Will Russian athletes be barred from competing at the 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Russian athletes are barred from competing at the 2024 Olympics under either (i) the Russian flag, (ii) The Russian Olympic Committee's flag, or (iii) any other independent or neutral flag. This will resolve based on the official list of countries and athletes present at the [2024 Olympics](https://olympics.com/en/olympic-games/paris-2024) or based on credible media reports, indicating that the 2024 Olympics are underway or have concluded without Russian participation. For the question to resolve as **Yes**, no more than 34 Russians can be competing at the 2024 Olympics. 34 was chosen as 10% of [Russian athletes that participated in the 2020 Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_Olympic_Committee_athletes_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics) to allow for a few individual or sport specific exceptions.

If more than 34 Russian athletes compete at the 2024 Olympics, this question will resolve as **No**.

If the 2024 Olympics are cancelled or postponed to 2025 or afterwards, this question resolves as ambiguously.

metadata.background_info:
After the [Russian's invasion of Ukraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine) in February 2022, Russia has been subject to a large amount of international pressure. That pressure has taken many different forms;  [sanctions](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/10266/russia-sanctions-1-year-after-invasion/), [boycotts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_boycott_of_Russia_and_Belarus), protests, oil and gas embargoes, corporate divestment, and more. Many individuals, corporations, and countries have taking action to show international solidarity with Ukraine.

In the sporting world, Russia has been banned from a number of recent international events. On Feb 28th 2022, four days after Russia invaded, FIFA made an unprecedented decision to [ban Russian clubs and the national team from all competitions](https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/mens/worldcup/qatar2022/media-releases/fifa-uefa-suspend-russian-clubs-and-national-teams-from-all-competitions) including the World Cup.

> Football is fully united here and in full solidarity with all the people affected in Ukraine. Both Presidents [FIFA and UEFA] hope that the situation in Ukraine will improve significantly and rapidly so that football can again be a vector for unity and peace amongst people.

In 2023, the IOC (International Olympic Committee) has reiterated their position several times [[1]](https://olympics.com/ioc/news/q-a-on-solidarity-with-ukraine-sanctions-against-russia-and-belarus-and-the-status-of-athletes-from-these-countries)[[2]](https://olympics.com/ioc/news/q-a-on-solidarity-with-ukraine-sanctions-against-russia-and-belarus-and-the-status-of-athletes-from-these-countries) that Russian and Belarusian athletes can only compete as Individual Neutral Athletes.

Despite IOC recommendations Poland banned Russian and Belarusian athletes from [the 2023 European Games](https://notesfrompoland.com/2023/03/29/russians-and-belarusians-banned-from-european-games-in-poland-despite-ioc-recommendations/). In Paris, the 2024 Olympic host city,  event organizers [cancelled a World Cup fencing event](https://apnews.com/article/fencing-france-russia-ukraine-2821983e726628c8bbf21e1eb8dd8c76) after the FIE (International Fencing Federation) [decision](https://apnews.com/article/fencing-russia-ukraine-olympics-9754e17d554df4484c609248019bd1a9) to allow Russian athletes to resume competing one year after the invasion of Ukraine. 

Looking back at previous Olympics, Russia's Track and Field team was [barred from the 2016 Olympics](https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/18/sports/olympics/russia-barred-rio-summer-olympics-doping.html) over a decade long doping scandal. 68 Athletes filled appeals that were ultimately [dismissed by the Court of Arbitration for Sport](https://www.nbcsports.com/bayarea/russians-lose-track-appeal-ioc-weigh-total-ban-rio), though [some](https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1133394/russia-ana-athletics) Russian athletes were able to compete as 'Authorized Neutral Athletes'. At the 2016 Paralympics the entire Russian Paralympic team was banned over the same doping scandal.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current geopolitical situation: The ongoing conflict between Russia and Ukraine has led to significant international sanctions against Russia, including in the sports world. 2. Historical precedent: Russian athletes were barred from competing under their national flag in the 2020 Tokyo Olympics and 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics due to doping scandals. They competed under the Russian Olympic Committee (ROC) flag. 3. International Olympic Committee (IOC) stance: In February 2023, the IOC announced it was exploring a pathway for Russian and Belarusian athletes to compete as neutral athletes, not representing their countries. 4. Opposition from other countries: Several countries, including Ukraine, Poland, and the Baltic states, have threatened to boycott the Olympics if Russian athletes are allowed to compete. 5. Time frame: The Olympics are still more than a year away, which leaves room for potential changes in the geopolitical landscape or IOC decisions. 6. Specific criteria in the question: The question resolves as "Yes" if no more than 34 Russian athletes compete, which is a very low number compared to previous Olympics. Given these factors, it seems likely that Russian athletes will face significant restrictions for the 2024 Olympics. While the IOC is considering allowing them to compete as neutral athletes, the ongoing war in Ukraine and international pressure may lead to stricter measures. The specific criterion of no more than 34 Russian athletes being allowed to compete makes it even more likely for this question to resolve as "Yes". This number is significantly lower than the number of Russian athletes who participated in previous Olympics, even under restrictions. However, there is still uncertainty due to the time remaining before the Olympics and potential changes in the global situation. The IOC's final decision is not yet known, and there's a possibility that a compromise solution could be reached that allows more than 34 Russian athletes to compete under neutral status. Considering all these factors, I estimate there is a high probability that Russian athletes will be barred from competing at the 2024 Olympics under the conditions specified in the question.

question.title: Will S&D hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the S&D holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other political groups. If two groups are tied for seats, both will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.background_info:
The [European Parliament](https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/government_in_ireland/european_government/eu_institutions/european_parliament.html#:~:text=The%20European%20Parliament%20is%20part,member%20states%20every%205%20years.) is a key legislative body within the European Union (EU) that shares lawmaking responsibilities with the Council of the European Union. Comprising [705](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/faq/11/how-many-meps) directly elected Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) from EU member states, the Parliament holds elections every five years. While it cannot initiate legislation, the European Parliament can approve, reject, or amend proposed laws, and it also supervises EU institutions and budgets.

During [European parliamentary elections](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/at-your-service/en/be-heard/elections), candidates run as representatives of their national parties, which are typically affiliated with political groups in the European Parliament. Once elected, Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) officially join political groups based on shared ideologies and policy objectives that align with their national parties. According to the [EU Parliament website](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/about-parliament/en/organisation-and-rules/organisation/political-groups), the following political groups are currently present in the European parliament:

| Group Name | Abbreviation |
|------------|--------------|
| Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) | EPP |
| Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament | S&D |
| Renew Europe Group | RE |
| Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance | Greens/EFA |
| Identity and Democracy Group | ID |
| European Conservatives and Reformists Group | ECR |
| The Left group in the European Parliament  | GUE/NGL |

In the [2019 elections](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/election-results-2019/en), the seats were allocated as follows between the political groups: 

| Group Name | Abbreviation | Seats |
|------------|--------------|-------|
| Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) | EPP | 182 |
| Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament | S&D | 154 |
| Renew Europe Group | RE | 108 |
| Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance | Greens/EFA | 74 |
| Identity and Democracy Group | ID | 73 |
| European Conservatives and Reformists Group | ECR | 62 |
| Non-Inscrits | NI | 57 |
| Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left | GUE/NGL | 41 |
| **Total Seats** | | **751** |


The next European parliamentary elections are [scheduled for 2024](https://multimedia.europarl.europa.eu/en/package/european-elections-2024_23001), with [polling](https://europeelects.eu/ep2024/) indicating a narrow lead for the EPP in early 2023.

reformat_metaculus_question.original_body:

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of S&D (Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats) holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current standings: As of the 2019 elections, the European People's Party (EPP) holds the most seats with 182, while S&D is second with 154 seats. This suggests that S&D would need to gain a significant number of seats to overtake EPP. 2. Recent trends: In recent years, there has been a general trend towards fragmentation in European politics, with traditional center-left and center-right parties losing ground to more extreme or populist parties. This could potentially hurt S&D's chances. 3. National political landscapes: The performance of S&D will depend on the success of its member parties in individual EU countries. Recent national elections in various EU countries have shown mixed results for center-left parties. 4. Brexit impact: The UK's departure from the EU has already affected the composition of the European Parliament, potentially altering the balance of power. 5. Current issues: The handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, economic recovery, climate change, and migration policies could influence voter preferences. S&D's stance on these issues will be crucial. 6. Rise of other groups: The performance of other groups like the Greens, Renew Europe, or right-wing parties could impact S&D's relative position. 7. Time until election: With the election still about a year away, there's potential for significant shifts in public opinion or unforeseen events that could impact the results. Given these factors, while S&D has a chance to gain seats, overtaking EPP seems challenging. The fragmentation of the political landscape and the rise of other parties make it difficult for any single group to dominate. However, S&D's position as the second-largest group gives them a strong starting point.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Renew holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, we need to consider several factors: 1. National politics: The performance of Renew will depend on the success of its member parties in individual EU countries. While some liberal parties have seen success (e.g., Macron's party in France), this is not consistent across all EU nations. 6. Time until election: The election is still about a year away, which leaves room for political shifts. However, major changes in the overall European political landscape are unlikely in this timeframe. 7. Fragmentation: The European Parliament is becoming more fragmented, with smaller groups gaining ground. This could potentially benefit Renew, but it also makes the political landscape more unpredictable. Given these factors, it seems unlikely that Renew will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections. While Renew may potentially improve its position, overtaking both the EPP and S&D would require an unprecedented shift in European politics. The most likely scenario is that Renew will remain the third or fourth largest group.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the Greens–EFA holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current representation: As of 2023, the Greens–EFA group holds 72 out of 705 seats in the European Parliament, making them the 4th largest group. This is significantly behind the largest groups like the European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D). 2. Historical performance: The Greens–EFA has never been the largest group in the European Parliament. Their best performance was in the 2019 elections when they gained seats but still remained the 4th largest group. 3. Political trends: While environmental issues have gained prominence in recent years, this hasn't translated into a dominant position for Green parties across Europe. Many voters concerned about environmental issues still support mainstream center-left or center-right parties. 4. National politics: The performance of Green parties varies significantly across EU member states. While they have seen some success in countries like Germany and France, they struggle in many Eastern European countries. 5. Competing issues: While climate change remains a significant concern, other issues like economic recovery post-COVID, inflation, and security concerns due to the war in Ukraine may take precedence for many voters. 6. Electoral system: The proportional representation system used in European elections makes it difficult for smaller parties to suddenly become the largest group without a massive shift in voter preferences across multiple countries. 7. Time until election: With the election still about a year away, there's time for political landscapes to change, but such a dramatic shift would be unprecedented. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that the Greens–EFA will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections. While they may potentially increase their seat share, overtaking the currently dominant groups like the EPP or S&D would require an extraordinary and unprecedented shift in voter preferences across multiple EU countries.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of ECR (European Conservatives and Reformists) holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, we need to consider several factors: 1. Political trends: There has been a rise in right-wing and Eurosceptic sentiment across Europe in recent years, which could potentially benefit ECR. However, this trend is not uniform across all EU member states. 3. Brexit impact: The UK's departure from the EU removed a significant number of ECR MEPs, weakening their position. They will need to make substantial gains to overcome this loss. 4. Fragmentation of right-wing parties: While there's a general trend towards right-wing politics, these parties are often divided between different European Parliament groups (ECR, ID, and some in EPP), which could limit ECR's ability to become the largest group. 5. Established parties' strength: Traditional center-right (EPP) and center-left (S&D) groups still maintain strong positions in many member states and have well-established networks and resources. 6. Time until election: With the election still about a year away, there's potential for significant shifts in public opinion or major events that could influence voting patterns. 7. Electoral system: The proportional representation system used in European Parliament elections makes it difficult for any single group to gain a dominant position. Given these factors, while ECR may gain seats in the 2024 elections, it seems unlikely that they will overcome the significant gap between their current position and that of the larger groups to become the group with the most seats. The established parties (EPP and S&D) have historically maintained their top positions, and while their dominance may be challenged, a complete overturn seems improbable. However, the possibility cannot be entirely ruled out, especially considering the volatile nature of current European politics and the potential for unexpected events or shifts in public opinion.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the ID (Identity and Democracy) political group holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, we need to consider several factors: 1. Time until the election: The election is still about a year away, and a lot can change in European politics during that time. 8. Historical precedent: No far-right group has ever held the most seats in the European Parliament, which suggests it would be a significant shift from historical patterns. While the ID group may well increase its seat share in the 2024 elections due to rising populism and fragmentation of traditional parties, it seems unlikely that they will gain enough seats to become the largest group. The gap between their current position (5th largest) and the top spot is substantial, and other major groups are likely to retain significant support. metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of GUE/NGL holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, we need to consider several factors: 1. Political landscape: The European political landscape remains diverse, with center-right and center-left parties still dominating in most countries. Far-right parties have seen more growth in recent years than far-left parties. 7. Seat allocation: The allocation of seats is based on population, which means larger countries have more influence. GUE/NGL would need to perform exceptionally well across multiple large countries to have a chance at becoming the largest group. Given these factors, it seems highly improbable that GUE/NGL will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections. question.title: Will Linda Yaccarino be the CEO of Twitter on July 1, 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Linda Yaccarino is in the position of CEO at Twitter on July 1, 2024, according to official announcements from Twitter or credible media sources.

metadata.background_info:
Linda Yaccarino, the former advertising chief of NBCUniversal, has been [appointed as the CEO of Twitter](https://edition.cnn.com/2023/05/12/tech/twitter-ceo-linda-yaccarino/index.html) by Elon Musk, the owner of the platform. She's expected to [assume the role in late June, 2023](https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1656748197308674048). The selection of Yaccarino indicates Musk's focus on Twitter's advertising business and his plans to revamp the social network into  [X, the “everything app”](https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/may/11/elon-musk-twitter-new-ceo).  Yaccarino has a strong background in the advertising industry and is known for her influential role in Madison Avenue.

Assuming the role of Twitter CEO, Yaccarino will face various challenges, including Twitter's struggles to expand its advertising business, gaps in expertise and technical glitches, and the company's substantial debt. Additionally, she will have to navigate the unpredictable nature of working with Musk.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Linda Yaccarino remaining CEO of Twitter on July 1, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Recent appointment: Linda Yaccarino was appointed as Twitter's CEO in May 2023, which means she will have been in the role for just over a year by July 2024. This is a relatively short time for a CEO tenure, which could work in favor of her remaining in the position. 2. Twitter's volatility: Twitter has experienced significant changes and challenges since Elon Musk's acquisition in 2022. The platform's stability and direction may still be in flux, which could impact leadership tenure. 3. Elon Musk's influence: As the owner of Twitter, Musk has shown a tendency to make sudden decisions and changes. His satisfaction with Yaccarino's performance will be crucial to her remaining in the role. 4. Yaccarino's background: She comes from a strong media background (former NBCUniversal advertising chief), which could be valuable for Twitter's advertising business. If she performs well in this area, it increases her chances of staying. 5. Twitter's performance: The company's financial and user growth performance under Yaccarino's leadership will be a significant factor. If Twitter shows improvement, her position is more secure. 6. Industry trends: The social media landscape is constantly evolving. Yaccarino's ability to adapt to new trends and challenges will affect her longevity as CEO. 7. Personal factors: Unknown personal circumstances could always play a role in a CEO's tenure. Given these factors, I believe there's a moderate to good chance that Yaccarino will remain CEO until July 1, 2024. The short time frame (about 13 months from her appointment) works in her favor, as does her relevant experience. However, the volatility of Twitter and Musk's unpredictable nature introduce significant uncertainty.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

metadata.background_info:
From [Reuters on May 24, 2023](https://www.reuters.com/technology/openai-may-leave-eu-if-regulations-bite-ceo-2023-05-24), "OpenAI CEO Sam Altman said on Wednesday the ChatGPT maker might consider leaving Europe if it could not comply with the upcoming artificial intelligence (AI) regulations by the European Union."

The [EU AI Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence_Act) "regulates the providers of artificial intelligence systems, and entities making use of them in a professional capacity." As of May 24, 2024, [Metaculus expects](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/8787/passing-of-the-ai-act/) the AI Act to be passed between Oct 2023 and Nov 2024, with a median of April 2024, though OpenAI could choose to cease offering ChatGPT in Europe earlier than that, or for some other reason entirely.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of ChatGPT being generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current availability: As of now (2023), ChatGPT is generally available in most EU countries, with some temporary exceptions like Italy in early 2023. 2. OpenAI's commitment to the EU market: OpenAI has shown interest in maintaining and expanding its presence in the EU, which suggests they are likely to work towards compliance with EU regulations. 3. EU regulations: The EU is developing AI regulations, including the AI Act, which could impact ChatGPT's availability. However, these regulations are still being finalized and are not expected to completely ban such technologies. 4. Time frame: The question is about availability on June 30, 2024, which gives OpenAI over a year to address any regulatory concerns and ensure compliance. 5. OpenAI's adaptability: The company has demonstrated willingness to adapt to regulatory requirements in the past, such as implementing age restrictions and addressing privacy concerns. 6. Potential for limited availability: The question allows for a positive resolution even if ChatGPT is unavailable to certain groups (e.g., minors) or in some EU countries, as long as >50% of the population can use it. 7. Technological advancements: By 2024, OpenAI is likely to have improved ChatGPT's capabilities and potentially addressed some of the current concerns regarding AI safety and ethics. 8. Competition and market pressure: The growing importance of AI technologies and competition from other companies may incentivize OpenAI to maintain its presence in the EU market. Considering these factors, it seems more likely than not that ChatGPT will be generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024. The main risks are potential regulatory hurdles, but given OpenAI's resources, adaptability, and the time frame involved, they are likely to overcome these challenges. However, there is still some uncertainty due to the evolving regulatory landscape and potential unforeseen issues.

question.title: Will Larry Elder be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Larry Elder is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, [saying at a rally in March 2022](https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-promises-to-return-to-the-white-house-in-2024-2022-3), "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before".  [Early polling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.  

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of [June 2022](https://floridapolitics.com/archives/531919-ron-desantis-swats-away-2024-speculation-yet-again/)), though Fox News producers have [called him](https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2021/08/13/inside-fox-news-desantis-is-the-future-of-the-party-and-hes-taking-advantage/) "the future of the Republican Party".  DeSantis is a frequent [second-place favorite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) in polling behind Trump.

Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; [in April 2022](https://archive.ph/uFSD4), when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Who will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? (Larry Elder)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** for the candidate below who is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election.  All other candidates will resolve as **No**.  This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who recieves the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election, it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Larry Elder becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current standing: Larry Elder is not currently considered a frontrunner for the Republican nomination. He has not officially announced his candidacy for the 2024 presidential race as of now. 2. Name recognition: While Elder gained some national attention during his 2021 California gubernatorial recall election campaign, his name recognition is still relatively low compared to other potential Republican candidates. 3. Political experience: Elder has never held elected office, which could be seen as a disadvantage in a presidential race. Voters and party officials often prefer candidates with more extensive political experience. 4. Fundraising ability: Running a successful presidential campaign requires significant financial resources. Elder's ability to raise the necessary funds for a national campaign is uncertain. 5. Competition: There are several high-profile Republicans who are either already running or considering running for the 2024 nomination, including Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley, and others. These candidates have stronger national profiles and more established support bases within the party. 6. Party support: There's no indication that Elder has significant support from Republican Party leadership or major donors, which would be crucial for securing the nomination. 7. Policy positions: While Elder's conservative views align with much of the Republican base, it's unclear if he has a unique policy platform that would set him apart from other candidates. 8. Time until convention: The Republican National Convention is still over a year away, which means there's time for the political landscape to change. However, this time frame also makes it more challenging for a lesser-known candidate like Elder to gain enough traction to secure the nomination. Given these factors, it appears highly unlikely that Larry Elder will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While it's not impossible, the odds are stacked against him due to his current low profile in the national political arena, lack of political experience, and the presence of more established and well-funded candidates in the race.

question.title: Will Anthropic publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, Anthropic publishes a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

metadata.background_info:
On July 21, 2023, the White House announced ([fact sheet](https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2023/07/21/fact-sheet-biden-harris-administration-secures-voluntary-commitments-from-leading-artificial-intelligence-companies-to-manage-the-risks-posed-by-ai/), [full report](https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/Ensuring-Safe-Secure-and-Trustworthy-AI.pdf)) that Amazon, Anthropic, Google, Inflection, Meta, Microsoft, and OpenAI have voluntarily committed to manage AI risks.

The voluntary commitments are in three categories (a) "Ensuring Products are Safe Before Introducing Them to the Public", (b) "Building Systems that Put Security First", and (c) "Earning the Public’s Trust", and are "designed to advance a generative AI legal and policy regime".

From [Microsoft](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-services/openai/concepts/red-teaming), "historically described systematic adversarial attacks for testing security vulnerabilities. With the rise of LLMs, the term has extended beyond traditional cybersecurity and evolved in common usage to describe many kinds of probing, testing, and attacking of AI systems." Note that this question only asks about _safety_, not _security_. [Google](https://bughunters.google.com/about/rules/6625378258649088/google-and-alphabet-vulnerability-reward-program-vrp-rules) and [OpenAI](https://bugcrowd.com/openai) already have bug bounties for security.

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Will these AI labs publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024? (Anthropic)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body: For each AI lab, this question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, they publish a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Anthropic's commitment to AI safety: Anthropic is known for its focus on AI safety and ethics. They have been vocal about the importance of developing safe and responsible AI systems. 2. Industry trends: There's an increasing trend in the AI industry towards transparency and external audits, especially for safety-critical aspects of AI systems. 3. Timeframe: The question gives almost a full year (from now until June 30, 2024) for this to happen, which is a reasonable amount of time to organize and conduct such an assessment. 4. External red-teaming: The requirement for external red-teaming adds complexity, as Anthropic would need to engage and coordinate with outside parties. 5. Public report: The requirement for a public report suggests a commitment to transparency, which aligns with Anthropic's stated values. 6. Regulatory pressure: With increasing scrutiny on AI companies, there may be growing pressure (regulatory or public) for companies to demonstrate their commitment to safety through external audits. 7. Competitive landscape: Other major AI companies (like OpenAI) have conducted and published results of external assessments, which might encourage Anthropic to do the same to remain competitive and maintain public trust. 8. Anthropic's past behavior: While I don't have specific information about Anthropic's past practices regarding external audits, their general approach to AI development suggests they would be open to such practices. Given these factors, I believe it's more likely than not that Anthropic will publish such a report. The company's focus on AI safety, the growing industry trend towards transparency, and the reasonable timeframe all point towards a higher probability. However, the requirements for external red-teaming and public reporting introduce some uncertainty.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. They have published numerous papers and reports on their AI developments. 2. Increasing focus on AI safety: There's growing concern and attention on AI safety in the tech industry and among policymakers. This pressure might encourage companies like DeepMind to be more transparent about their safety measures. 3. Competitive landscape: Other major AI companies like OpenAI have published reports on model safety and external evaluations. DeepMind might feel compelled to do the same to maintain their reputation and competitive edge. 4. Time frame: The question gives almost a full year (from July 2023 to June 2024) for this to happen, which is a considerable amount of time in the fast-moving field of AI. 5. External red-teaming: While internal safety checks are common, external red-teaming adds an extra layer of credibility. DeepMind might see this as a way to build trust with the public and policymakers. 6. Recent developments: In May 2023, DeepMind released a report on the potential risks of frontier AI systems, showing their willingness to engage with safety concerns publicly. 7. Regulatory pressure: As governments worldwide consider AI regulations, companies might proactively demonstrate their commitment to safety to influence policy discussions. However, there are also factors that might reduce the likelihood: 1. Competitive secrecy: DeepMind might be hesitant to allow external parties to closely examine their models due to intellectual property concerns. 2. Potential negative findings: If the red-teaming uncovers significant safety issues, DeepMind might be reluctant to publish the results. 3. Resource allocation: Conducting and publishing such a report requires time and resources, which DeepMind might prefer to allocate elsewhere. Considering these factors, I believe it's more likely than not that DeepMind will publish such a report by the given date, but it's far from certain.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be charged with witness tampering in Georgia before June 1, 2024?
question.body: The question resolves **Yes** if Donald Trump is charged or indicted for any statements related to potential witnesses in *[The State of Georgia v. Donald J. Trump, et al](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosecution_of_Donald_Trump_in_Georgia)*. The indictments must occur before June 1, 2024.

metadata.background_info:
On August 14, 2023, former President Donald Trump was [indicted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosecution_of_Donald_Trump_in_Georgia#Indictment) by a grand jury in Georgia, alongside 18 other individuals. The state brought charges against Trump related to Trump's alleged participation in an attempt to overturn the state's 2020 presidential election results.

Trump made statements on his social media platform, Truth Social, which [appeared to warn](https://www.axios.com/2023/08/14/trump-witness-tampering-georgia-indictment) potential witnesses not to testify against him.

> Former President Donald Trump posted on Truth Social, his social media platform, on Monday saying Georgia’s former Lt. Gov. Geoff Duncan “shouldn’t” testify in grand jury proceedings this week regarding allegations that Trump attempted to overturn the 2020 election results in the state—and some legal analysts are saying the post could be witness intimidation or tampering.

> ...

> Per Georgia law, anyone who attempts to [influence](https://law.justia.com/codes/georgia/2020/title-16/chapter-10/article-5/section-16-10-93/) a witness is subject to felony charges and, if convicted, can face one to five years in prison; anyone who [threatens](https://law.justia.com/codes/georgia/2022/title-16/chapter-10/article-2/section-16-10-32/#:~:text=Attempted%20Murder%20or%20Threatening%20of%20Witnesses%20in%20Official%20Proceedings,-Universal%20Citation%3A%20GA&text=shall%20be%20guilty%20of%20a,nor%20more%20than%2020%20years.) a witness is subject to felony charges and, if convicted, faces 10 to 20 years in prison. ([Forbes](https://www.forbes.com/sites/mollybohannon/2023/08/14/trump-suggested-a-witness-shouldnt-testify-in-georgias-grand-jury-proceedings-critics-say-thats-witness-intimidation/?sh=7e14b52a57be))

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Donald Trump being charged with witness tampering in Georgia before June 1, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Existing indictment: Trump has already been indicted in Georgia on 13 counts related to efforts to overturn the 2020 election results. This shows that prosecutors are willing to bring charges against him. 2. Ongoing investigation: The Georgia case is still active, and prosecutors may continue to gather evidence and potentially add charges. 3. Trump's behavior: Trump has a history of making public statements that could be construed as attempts to influence witnesses or the legal process. If he continues this behavior specifically related to the Georgia case, it could lead to additional charges. 4. Time frame: The question gives a deadline of June 1, 2024, which is about 9 months from now. This provides a significant window for prosecutors to bring additional charges if they find evidence of witness tampering. 5. Precedent: Witness tampering charges are not uncommon in high-profile cases, especially when defendants make public statements about potential witnesses. 6. Political considerations: Given the high-profile nature of the case and Trump's status as a former president and potential candidate, prosecutors may be cautious about bringing additional charges without strong evidence. 7. Legal threshold: Prosecutors would need to have clear evidence of witness tampering that meets the legal definition in Georgia to bring such charges. Considering these factors, while it's possible that Trump could be charged with witness tampering, it's not highly probable. The existing indictment covers many aspects of Trump's alleged interference in the 2020 election, and prosecutors may feel they have already addressed the most significant issues. However, if Trump makes statements that clearly attempt to influence witnesses in the Georgia case, the probability would increase. Given the information available and the timeframe, I would estimate a moderate to low probability of this occurring.
